conclusion: To determine the time at which objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze their positions over time by comparing the areas under their respective velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The area under the curve for object A from time \( t = 0 \) to \( t = t_2 \) can be calculated by integrating its velocity function over that interval.
The area under the curve for object B from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = t_2 \) needs to be calculated.

premise: The areas under the curves for objects A and B represent their displacements.
conclusion: The difference in displacement between the two objects at any time \( t \) is given by the difference in the areas under their respective v-t curves up to that time.

premise: The difference in displacement is given by the difference in the areas under the v-t curves.
conclusion: We need to find the time \( t \) at which this difference is maximized.

premise: The time of maximum separation involves finding the time \( t \) where the rate of change of the difference in displacement is zero.
conclusion: This corresponds to the point where the slopes of the two curves are equal, i.e., where the velocities of A and B are equal.
At \( t_1 \), the velocity of object B is greater than that of object A, causing B to move ahead.
At \( t_2 \), the velocity of object A becomes greater than that of object B.

premise: The velocities of A and B are equal between \( t_1 \) and \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The point where the velocities are equal is somewhere between \( t_1 \) and \( t_2 \). This is the point where the difference in their displacements is maximized.

premise: The maximum separation occurs between \( t_1 \) and \( t_2 \) when velocities are equal.
conclusion: Therefore, at time \( t_2 \), the distance between the two reaches its maximum.
